citation.article-title: A new species of soil bacteria of the genus Prosthecomicrobium.

p.s: Description of Prosthecomicrobium mishustinii sp. nov.
Prosthecomicrobium mishustinii (mi.shus.tinii, is named after E. N. Mishustin, the famous Soviet microbiologist)
The cells are short thick rodes of varied size, 0.6-0.9 to 0.-8-1.2 μm in diameter and 0.8-0.95 to 1.3-1.5 μm long.
Single or paired.
Nonmotile The prosthecae are from 0.20-0.30 μm to 0.4-0.65 μm long, 0.20-0.25 μm in diameter, cylindrical, slightly narrowed to the apex.
Prosthecae are loosely located in the cell.
The cells reproduce by budding, the buds are fixed, with prosthecae getting detached when the cells reach the size of the mother cell.
They are aerobes, catalase and oxidase positive.
Colonies are yellowish-orange, rounded, of a thick consistency detachable from agar as a whole.
They dissociate yielding pigmentless variants.

The organism is a chemoorganotroph, utilizing many mono- and disaccharides and some sugar alcohols as a single carbon and energy source, tri- and polysaccharides are not utilized, but organic acids of the Krebs cycles and some amino acids are (Tables 2 and 3).
Yeast extract or B group vitamins are required for growth.
Hydrolytic activity is absent.
The optimal growth temperature is 28-30°C, pH neutral.
The cells are extremely sensitive to penicillin, MPK 0.01-0.05 μm/ml (6).
The habitat: the organism is widespread in soils, manure and in places when the degradation of organic material is rapid.
It was found in soils of Colchis, in hotbed soil and in horse manure.
The GC-content of DNA is from 63.7 to 65.2 mol% (by hear denaturation).
It differs from most closely related species in the degree of DNA/DNA homology, cell size and prosthecae length.
The typical strain 17 has been deposited with the Institute of Microbiology, the USSR Academy of Sciences, Moscow, USSR.
